author: Potter
text: Once upon a time there was a village shop.

author: Potter
text: The name over the window was "Ginger and Pickles."

author: Potter
text: It was a little small shop just the right size for Dolls-- Lucinda and Jane Doll-cook always bought their groceries at Ginger and Pickles.

author: Potter
text: The counter inside was a convenient height for rabbits.

author: Potter
text: Ginger and Pickles sold red spotty pocket handkerchiefs at a penny three farthings.

author: Potter
text: They also sold sugar, and snuff and galoshes.

author: Potter
text: In fact, although it was such a small shop it sold nearly everything--except a few things that you want in a hurry--like bootlaces, hair- pins and mutton chops.

author: Potter
text: Ginger and Pickles were the people who kept the shop.

author: Potter
text: Ginger was a yellow tomcat, and Pickles was a terrier.

author: Potter
text: The rabbits were always a little bit afraid of Pickles.

author: Potter
text: The shop was also patronized by mice--only the mice were rather afraid of Ginger.

author: Potter
text: Ginger usually requested Pickles to serve them, because he said it made his mouth water.

author: Potter
text: "I cannot bear," said he, "to see them going out at the door carrying their little parcels."

author: Potter
text: "I have the same feeling about rats," replied Pickles, "but it would never do to eat our customers; they would leave us and go to Tabitha Twitchit's."

author: Potter
text: "On the contrary, they would go nowhere," replied Ginger gloomily.

author: Potter
text: (Tabitha Twitchit kept the only other shop in the village.

author: Potter
text: She did not give credit.)

author: Potter
text: But there is no money in what is called the "till."

author: Potter
text: Ginger and Pickles gave unlimited credit.

author: Potter
text: Now the meaning of "credit" is this--when a customer buys a bar of soap, instead of the customer pulling out a purse and paying for it --she says she will pay another time.

author: Potter
text: And Pickles makes a low bow and says, "With pleasure, madam," and it is written down in a book.

author: Potter
text: The customers come again and again, and buy quantities, in spite of being afraid of Ginger and Pickles.

author: Potter
text: The customers came in crowds every day and bought quantities, especially the toffee customers.

author: Potter
text: But there was always no money; they never paid for as much as a penny- worth of peppermints.

author: Potter
text: But the sales were enormous, ten times as large as Tabitha Twitchit's.

author: Potter
text: As there was always no money, Ginger and Pickles were obliged to eat their own goods.

author: Potter
text: Pickles ate biscuits and Ginger ate a dried haddock.

author: Potter
text: They ate them by candle- light after the shop was closed.

author: Potter
text: "It is very uncomfortable, I am afraid I shall be summoned.

author: Potter
text: I have tried in vain to get a license upon credit at the Post Office;" said Pickles.

author: Potter
text: "The place is full of policemen.

author: Potter
text: I met one as I was coming home.

author: Potter
text: "Let us send in the bill again to Samuel Whiskers, Ginger, he owes 22/9 for bacon."

author: Potter
text: "I do not believe that he intends to pay at all," replied Ginger.

author: Potter
text: When it came to Jan. 1st there was still no money, and Pickles was unable to buy a dog license.

author: Potter
text: "It is very unpleasant, I am afraid of the police," said Pickles.

author: Potter
text: "It is your own fault for being a terrier; _I_ do not require a license, and neither does Kep, the Collie dog."

author: Potter
text: "And I feel sure that Anna Maria pockets things--

author: Potter
text: "Where are all the cream crackers?"

author: Potter
text: "You have eaten them yourself." replied Ginger.

author: Potter
text: Ginger and Pickles retired into the back parlor.

author: Potter
text: They did accounts.

author: Potter
text: They added up sums and sums, and sums.

author: Potter
text: "Samuel Whiskers has run up a bill as long as his tail; he has had an ounce and three- quarters of snuff since October.

author: Potter
text: "What is seven pounds of butter at 1/3, and a stick of sealing wax and four matches?"

author: Potter
text: "Send in all the bills again to everybody `with compliments,'" replied Ginger.

author: Potter
text: Pickles nearly had a fit, he barked and he barked and made little rushes.

author: Potter
text: "Bite him, Pickles! bite him!" spluttered Ginger behind a sugar barrel, "he's only a German doll!"

author: Potter
text: The policeman went on writing in his notebook; twice he put his pencil in his mouth, and once he dipped it in the treacle.

author: Potter
text: Pickles barked till he was hoarse.

author: Potter
text: But still the policeman took no notice.

author: Potter
text: He had bead eyes, and his helmet was sewed on with stitches.

author: Potter
text: After a time they heard a noise in the shop, as if something had been pushed in at the door.

author: Potter
text: They came out of the back parlor.

author: Potter
text: There was an envelope lying on the counter, and a policeman writing in a notebook!

author: Potter
text: At length on his last little rush--Pickles found that the shop was empty.

author: Potter
text: The policeman had disappeared.

author: Potter
text: But the envelope remained.

author: Potter
text: "Do you think that he has gone to fetch a real live policeman?

author: Potter
text: I am afraid it is a summons," said Pickles.

author: Potter
text: "No," replied Ginger, who had opened the envelope, "it is the rates and taxes, 3 pounds 19 11 3/4." [pounds are British money, the 19 is schillings, and then pence]

author: Potter
text: "This is the last straw," said Pickles, "let us close the shop."

author: Potter
text: They put up the shutters, and left.

author: Potter
text: But they have not removed from the neighborhood.

author: Potter
text: In fact some people wish they had gone further.

author: Potter
text: Ginger is living in the warren [game preserve for rabbits].

author: Potter
text: I do not know what occupation he pursues; he looks stout and comfortable.

author: Potter
text: Pickles is at present a game- keeper.

author: Potter
text: After a time Mr. John Dormouse and his daughter began to sell peppermints and candles.

author: Potter
text: But they did not keep "self- fitting sixes"; and it takes five mice to carry one seven inch candle.

author: Potter
text: The closing of the shop caused great inconvenience.

author: Potter
text: Tabitha Twitchit immediately raised the price of everything a halfpenny; and she continued to refuse to give credit.

author: Potter
text: Of course there are the tradesmen's carts--the butcher, the fishman and Timothy Baker.

author: Potter
text: But a person cannot live on "seed wigs" and sponge cake and butter buns--not even when the sponge cake is as good as Timothy's!

author: Potter
text: And Miss Dormouse refused to take back the ends when they were brought back to her with complaints.

author: Potter
text: And when Mr. John Dormouse was complained to, he stayed in bed, and would say nothing but "very snug;" which is not the way to carry on a retail business.

author: Potter
text: Besides--the candles which they sell behave very strangely in warm weather.

author: Potter
text: So everybody was pleased when Sally Henny Penny sent out a printed poster to say that she was going to reopen the shop--"Henny's Opening Sale!

author: Potter
text: Grand cooperative Jumble!

author: Potter
text: Penny's penny prices!

author: Potter
text: Come buy, come try, come buy!"

author: Potter
text: The poster really was most 'ticing.

author: Potter
text: There was a rush upon the opening day.

author: Potter
text: The shop was crammed with customers, and there were crowds of mice upon the biscuit cannisters.

author: Potter
text: Sally Henny Penny gets rather flustered when she tries to count out change, and she insists on being paid cash; but she is quite harmless.

author: Potter
text: And she has laid in a remarkable assortment of bargains.

author: Potter
text: There is something to please everybody.
